head.title: Can Siberia Teach Us About Heating?

hedline.hl1: Can Siberia Teach Us About Heating?

block.p: "Verkhoyansk Journal: A Siberian Icebox That Holds a Thousand People" (news article, Sept. 3) has important information about home heating in very cold weather. "Verkhoyansk Journal: A Siberian Icebox That Holds a Thousand People" (news article, Sept. 3) has important information about home heating in very cold weather. You state that it takes seven truckloads of wood costing $1,650 to heat a modest house each winter in Verkhoyansk, Russia, where temperatures drop to as low as -90 degrees Fahrenheit.

The maximum difference between indoor and outdoor temperature in Verkhoyansk is about 150 degrees, or about three times what it is in many areas of the globe that require winter heating. Those concerned with home heating, and who have access to wood, might well find it useful to learn how wood is burned by the residents of Verkhoyansk.

Do the Siberians have wood-burning techniques and appliances from which we might benefit? Or can we help them with our own technical advances in the use of wood fuel -- the globe's most important source of renewable energy?

Verkhoyansk may be an icebox to live in, but it could be a hothouse for ideas about home heating in winter, with benefits for energy conservation, wood-burning practices and appliances. LAWRENCE CRANBERG President, Texas Fireframe Company Austin, Tex., Sept. 5, 1994
